segments.text: When you contacted seismic studies prior to World War II in terms of work, has the equipment changed a great deal since then, would you say?
Or has it remained rather constant?
No, there's been great improvements to equipment, largely due to the oil companies.
The refraction seismic technique, I don't think I need to explain what it's all about, is much the same.
But the refraction technique has
become extremely sophisticated from the point of view of data processing.
You now have hundreds of instruments out and combine them in quite subtle ways, combine the signals in quite subtle ways.
This, of course, is caused partly by the extraordinary change in electronics.
You see, one of the striking things in my life that has affected science so greatly is the change in electronics.
There have been three major changes.
When I was a young man, electronics worked with vacuum tubes, and this went on right up to something like 1950.
No, later than that, almost 55 or 56, the vacuum tube was king, and everything had vacuum tubes in it.
They were large, they were unreliable, they broke, they were an absolute pest, and I remember there was a joke
saying there's nothing wrong with electronics which couldn't be cured by getting rid of the vacuum tube, which was, of course, the only electronic component, practically.
Well, then the invention of the transistor made a difference.

And I remember very well making the decision in my own lab that in future we would use transistors unless there was some reason to the contrary to use valves, that our standard would be to use transistors.
Well, in about a couple of years, you could buy...
little packages containing perhaps half a dozen transistors and doing some function like some logical function or a counting function or something of this kind.
Well then we made another decision.
We decided we wouldn't solder together our own transistors.
We'd buy the little package units unless there was some reason to the contrary.
Well that lasted some years and then suddenly we got integrated circuits and we got things a few millimeters across which would do these functions.
So you had the three
the four things, the three transitions, in this very short time, really, since the late 50s.
And this is the thing that's made all the difference.
It's the same thing, of course, that's produced the pocket computers, things you couldn't conceive of doing.
You can be much more fancy in your data analysis.
You've probably heard about Walter Monk's ocean-bottom capsules.
These are all dependent on this kind of thing.
And all through science, it's
may be possible to do things that you really couldn't have done before.
And seismic reflection shooting is one of the critical things.
Would you describe your instrument for measuring heat values?
Would I describe it?
Yes.
Well, it's all in the literature, of course, but I'll certainly describe it.
It was a tube about 10 feet long, a little over an inch in diameter,
which contained the original apparatus you want, the one we started with.
The first one we had, the temperature measurements were made by thermocouples.

We had copper constant and thermocouples in it, and we measured the temperature difference between the bottom of the tube and the top of the tube, and the middle of the tube and the top of the tube, so that we got two temperature differences.

the wires from these thermocouples ran into a pressure-tight container at the top, fastened onto the top of the tube, and the whole thing was lowered down into the sea on a wire, and when it got near the bottom, we arranged for it to be dropped and to go rapidly, shoot down into the bottom, and this tube penetrated in 10 feet or 15 feet, whatever its length was.
You left it there for half an hour and then pulled it out again.
This I developed here in La Jolla in the summer of 1949 with Art Maxwell, who was a graduate student.
And you built this in the lab?
I built it myself in the scripts workshops with my own hands and Maxwell's hands.
And so you in effect knew about what you wanted.
Was there any other
temperature measuring device which gave you clues on how to build it?
First of all, at one point I think we got wrong.
I thought of this before the war, but we actually did it after the war in 1949.
I think you asked me the question in terms of what we did before the war.
I measured heat flow on land in England and South Africa before the war.
I had the idea of measuring it at sea before the war, but I didn't actually get it done until after the war.
And this apparatus
This first one we built here never actually worked.

It was clearly possible there were trivial things wrong with it, and Art Maxwell built a thing with a rather different recording arrangement, and I built one like the original one in England, and they both worked.
Sorry, you asked me a question.
No, you've answered it.
I was wondering where you got the idea.
The answer is I suppose... Oh, no, let me say a little more about it.
Just before we did the job here, a man, Norwegian, whose name escapes me, I'll remember it in a minute, had the same idea independently, and he was a Dane.
The Danes had a round-the-world trip, oceanographic, ocean floor trip, just in the early, middle 50s.
I think it was the early 50s, I think, and he actually used this apparatus, I think, before we got ours to work.
He didn't get any results.
He got some temperature differences, but what they, undoubtedly, they were due to friction on pushing the thing in.
When the spike goes in, it rubs on the sediments and warms itself up, and you have to leave it in for something like half an hour on the sizes we had.
to settle down.
Otherwise, you get two or three times too high a value.
And he got absurd.
Well, some of the results were reasonable and some of them were absurd.
And I think no one has, they've never been quoted again.
And I think they were beyond question wrong.
But he has, in a sense, the priority on it.
And I'm only sorry I can't remember his name.
He's a well-known Danish oceanographer who went on this round-the-world trip, mostly collecting sediments.
Afterwards, Maxwell and various people made smaller versions of it in which you don't have to leave it quite so long.
You can leave it for 10 minutes instead of half an hour, and this is quite a help.
Of course, the ship always pulled my apparatus and bent the probe, so I always, every time, I had to straighten it.
When you went to Toronto, did you have any innovations in mind as far as changing the nature of the department or the faculty there?
Well, I didn't know much about it, of course, when I went.
I'd never been there, and so I could hardly go with much idea.

I went with a certain apprehension because there was a geophysical section there run by Jock Wilson, J. Tuzo Wilson, who was a very old friend of mine, and I thought he might feel that to have another geophysicist come in as head of the department was, in a sense,
detrimental to him, but he was extremely good about it.
And the thing, one of the things I was interested in was boosting up this project.
It was a very, rather small project, and I was only there for two years.
We did expand it quite a bit.
And, I mean, I'd left pure physics 10 years, 20 years before nearly, and it...
was obviously a thing I had to feel my way with a bit to take over, take charge of a very large physics department.
There were interesting things going there.
They were doing work on developing the electron microscope.
They were doing work on spectroscopy, which I didn't know much about.
Some low temperature work.
There were quite nice things going on there.
Then I got very interested in
the setting up of a computer center there.
I mean, 49 was early days for this.
And we set up one of the first of the things that all universities now have, a computer center.
So I had an interesting time there.
What about at Admiralty when you were in operational research there?
Did you try to bring any new ideas into Admiralty?
Well, what we were interested in doing was examining, we regarded operations analysis
as the examination of past operations to understand what happened and why, and to use this information in the planning of future operations.
The critical, probably the most important project in that group, this group was run by Patrick Blackett, the most important project, I think, was the arguments about the size of convoys.
a considerable split in the Navy about the proper size for convoys.
I mean, on the obvious difficulty, if a convoy is very large, it's conspicuous, and you may lose a lot of ships if it's attacked.
If a convoy is very small, it'll have to have rather few defensive vessels, rather few escort vessels, because there'll be more convoys to divide the escort vessels between.
Where does the balance come?
How fast does a ship have to be not to go in convoy at all?
These kinds of questions, fascinating questions.
I didn't have very much to do with this.
I knew all about it, and I talked about it continuously.
But Blackett and some other people, Henry Hume particularly, did most of this.
My own main interest, I think, I was interested in arguments about the use of air power.
whether we should use it on flying bombs, whether one should divert aircraft from the bombing of Germany to coastal command.

This has all been published now, this great controversy about the use of air power, how far it was desirable to use aeroplanes to knock down German housing, and how far it was better to concentrate on particular objectives.
And I spent a lot of time
on intelligence connection with this.

And then, as I told you yesterday, I was very interested in, very much concerned with the German development of the V weapons, the flying bombs and the rockets, and getting an understanding of what was likely to happen, what ought to be done about it.
A very important question, of course, because these things were very embarrassingly likely to arrive just before
the invasion of France.
And we didn't quite know how the British public would react.
It obviously depended on the intensity of the attack on London, whether they would demand that they be defended from this, and we'd have to cut down the effort in France.
I mean, it was extremely important to understand what was likely to happen.
And in fact, we managed, by destroying the sites, to postpone the attack until after the landings in France.
We were lucky that way, I think.
Because there was a great argument as to whether it was necessary to land in France.
The Air Force believed, for emotional reasons, that if you knocked down 30% of all the houses in Germany, you would, in fact, end the war.
This turned out not to be true, but a really terrible thing, deliberately to go out and use air power to destroy housing and kill civilians.
It's one of the great war crimes, of course, by anything but our current standards.
I mean, by any standards of war from the 17th century to now, it is a war crime.
But, of course, things have now changed so much, and the attack on civilians, the killing of civilians, and the destruction of their houses is now an accepted part of war.
But the thing about it that I felt very strongly at the time
Now, to begin today then with fresh questions, from the last time we talked, you had in effect resigned at Toronto and were taking a new direction in your career.
Well, I came home and I became the bottom man on the totem pole.
An eccentric thing to do.
I thought at the time I wanted peace and quiet to get on with my own work.
A great many scientists, particularly scientists who had the experience of the war, have oscillated between a desire for power and influence and a desire to do their own work.
The outstanding example was the treasurer of the National Academy, Bob Robertson.
Bob Robertson was an expert on relativity.
And Bob Robertson came over during the war, and I remember telling him,
But there was no good coming over and talking about new gadgets he wanted made and all this kind of thing.
I said, just wasting your time.
The war's nearly over.
The only thing that matters is to use what we've got and get on with it.
And I don't want to talk about whether you can make a better death charge.
I'm just not interested.
And he got this point and became an enthusiastic supporter of operations analysis.
A very successful, very influential man.
talking all the time about how he wanted to get back to his relativity at Caltech.
Well, the war ended.
He went back to relativity at Caltech.
Before a year or so was over, he was saying he felt it wasn't relevant.
He felt he ought to be doing something useful.
Morphy went and became chief scientist to NATO, I believe.
And this cycle was repeated several times until eventually he got killed in a road crash.
But this is true of many people, this oscillation between positions

of moderate power and influence and positions in which you can just deal with graduate students and try and teach people what the world is like and how things work and get on with the things you're interested in.
Well this was one of these switches that I decided I could have had various jobs.
I was offered the directorship of the atomic weapons establishment in England at the same time and I refused it.
I could have done
almost anything I'd wanted to do.
At the end of the war, I was offered the job of Chief Scientist of the Air Force.
Many, many jobs.
There was always this choice, and to some extent, the oscillation between the two things.
Well, anyway, I went back to Cambridge, and this has been a success.
Somewhere in one of C.P.
Snow's novels, he has a case of this sort, and says that he's noticed
how often it is successful where people like Charles V of Spain, resigning as emperor and going into a monastery.
Snow doesn't quote this, but it's another example.
It's a common human thing to do, and I'm sure when Snow wrote this, he was thinking of me, because we talked about it not very long before.
Well, anyway, I went back to Cambridge to this job,
as assistant director of research with this man, Brown, who was a lot younger than me and I'd worked with as a young man, and he was head of the department.
And I had to, of course, be frankly careful not to tread on his toes or to attempt to run the department.
I had to sit in the background and let him do what he wanted to do, so to speak.
I had some difficulty in refraining
from getting the department involved in the International Geophysical Year.
He wanted, for some reason best known to himself, to have nothing at all to do with the International Geophysical Year.
I think he just thought he'd be a nuisance.
He was a rather half-hearted geophysicist.
He was an awfully nice man, a very able man, but really fairly half-hearted about actually doing any work.
He was, I think, a country gentleman at heart, really.
And he died of cancer.
or about ten years ago, I suppose.
But before that, he decided to resign as head of the department.
And so I became head of the department.
And at this time, or about that time, or a little before, the university had promoted me to my old grade as reader.
So we both were readers, and I took the job as head of the department.
And we were, by that time, in quite a mess.
And I went into it with this man called Morris Hill, who had been a graduate student with me after the war, and I'd known him during the war.
He was the son of A.V.
Hill, the Secretary of the Royal Society, the physiologist, the man who was in charge of this committee looking into scientific manpower that I mentioned yesterday.
Well, his son was in the lab, and he was getting very depressed and upset, and I had a long talk with him.
And I decided that what we lacked was money.
So I said, well, why don't I get some money?
So we got a lot of money.
We got $50,000 a year from the Office of Naval Research, which was reasonable.
It was my appreciable money in those days, it isn't now.
And we got money from here and there.
And soon we were really quite well set up.
And we went into the marine work, marine geology, on quite a scale.
We had an extensive operation in the Indian Ocean.

um during there was an international um i forget what it's called the international indian ocean expedition there are lots of different nationalities sent ships to the indian ocean i didn't go but a lot of our people went well so that when i became head of the department again i went through a moderate expansion looking back i didn't expand it enough i decided
that I wanted to aim at 20 graduate students.
So we went up to 20 graduate students and a staff of about five.
We didn't get any appreciable increase of money from the university, but we simply, in fact, the university money was practically negligible.
It paid my salary and a couple of other salaries and nothing much else.
And I got the money from all kinds of places outside.
And then, a little later on,
I saw the writing on the wall that this country wasn't going on indefinitely financing Europe, scientific enterprises in Europe.
And when our contract with ONR ran out, I decided not to try and get it renewed.
I was sure it was going to go, and I wouldn't get it renewed, and so I decided to use the fact that this wasn't being renewed to put pressure to get money from the British government.
So we got quite good contracts, grants rather,
with the old Department of Scientific and Industrial Research in England and its various successors, the Natural Environment Research Council.
They've been our main finance since that.
And we've been adequately financed for the level we were working at.
I think, looking back, we ought to have aimed at a 50% higher level.
But we didn't really do it.
But we've had very distinguished people.

numerous fellows of the Royal Society, and we had played a very large part in the revolution in geology, the transition from the idea of fixed continents, no global theory, to the ideas of Wegener and the ideas that you could have a global theory of why the Earth worked like it did.
Our main theme since

I went back there in, I went back in 56 and I would say the main theme of that department in Cambridge since 58 has been a global view of geology, particularly the mechanism of geology as exemplified in the sea floor.
I should like to ask two questions right here if I could.
What finally became of the explanation of low values you found in the Pacific, speaking of heat values in the Pacific floor?
Did we find those values?
Yes, you did.
Well, they were very variable.
I mean, there are very high values along the ocean ridge.
Right.
And there are lower values on each side, some of which are exceptionally low.
And the general decrease of heat flow away from the ridge is qualitatively well explained by the ideas of the motion of the sea floor away from the axis.
It's a somewhat curious situation at the moment.
One gets a very good account of the slope from the ridge down on each side.
I mean, it's a very striking feature of the sea floor that the deepest places are quite close to the continental edge and the shallowest places are in the middle.
I mean, this is not what anyone would expect of an ocean.
And the reason is because new ocean floor is being formed, all hot,

by volcanoes on the ridge and these volcanoes keep erupting and it keeps splitting open and you're forming new sea floor on the axis of the ridge and the sea floor on each side is moving away and as it goes of course it cools and contracts and the increased depth of the sea is very well accounted for quantitatively by the cooling.
The heat flow is not so good quantitatively.

Various people, mostly students of mine, are working on this now, and I was talking to Dan McKenzie, who's the brightest man on this stuff, and he tells me there's a man at MIT, an old student of ours, who now has a rational explanation of this, but I'm afraid I can't remember what it is.
But you began working with that, though, with these ideas really in the 50s while you were... Well, what I wanted to do, you see, I was fairly convinced
that the Earth's heat was the ultimate cause of geological change, that the Earth is a heat engine.

And the question of whether the Earth is cooling, whether the Earth is heating up, how the heat flow varies from place to place, was obviously one of the critical things about the Earth, which wasn't understood, wasn't known, hardly.
You see, the increase of temperature in mines was, as far as I know, discovered
in the middle of the 17th century.

You would think that it would have been known to Agricola in the 16th century, and whilst I haven't read Agricola's enormous works in Latin all the way through, I have made a fair search, and it appears that he doesn't know that it's hot in mines.
Very surprising, and I don't understand why, and I want to read some of his obscurer works to see whether he really did know, but those are

French Jesuit theologian, astrologer, scientist of a sort in the beginning, somewhere about 1620, the beginning of the 17th century, who remarks that the mines in what's now Czechoslovakia and Bohemia are hot in them.
And there's a beautiful, very interesting travel book by Edward Brown, the son of
Brown, who wrote the essays.
Brown, what's his name?
Doesn't really matter.
Well-known 17th century essayist who lived in Norwich, England.
Well, his son was a doctor who went out to the mines in Bohemia and gives a very good account of how it gets warm as you go down them.
And Boyle, he was a friend of Boyle's, Robert Boyle's, whose joke about Boyle that he was the father of chemistry and the nephew of the Earl of Cork.
Well, anyway, he wrote about the heat inside the Earth.
And then really no one paid any attention to it.
There's extraordinarily few references to it from these very interesting papers of Boyle in about 1660, way down until our own times.
And then Kelvin got interested.
Kelvin was interested in it in connection with the age of the Earth.
There's a very interesting book that's been published by Joe Birchfield, who you may know.
Joe Birchfield of Northern Illinois, I think.
He wrote a book on Kelvin and the age of the Earth.
I've written a review of it, which I will give you.
And Kelvin set up a committee, a committee of the British Association,
to measure heat flow from the Earth.
You have to measure not only temperature gradients, which is relatively easy, but also the thermal conductivity of the rocks.
And this committee was very active for 10 or 15 years.
And then again, the subject died and nothing happened until Jeffreys suggested to me in the middle 1930s that we ought to do something about it.
And we started to do something about it.
We developed methods of measuring thermal conductivity of relatively small pieces of rock, methods of making the specimens,
all this kind of thing.
And I went to South Africa and worked the western temperature measurements in boreholes and mines there, and I collected specimens and measured thermal conductivity and so on.
And I had students working in England on it, or one student anyway.
And so we got well into heat flow on land before the war, and then after the war decided to do it at sea.
We had to take cores and measure the thermal conductivity of the material.
Afterwards, Morris Ewing at Columbia
developed a method in which you measured the temperatures and took the cores at the same time.
And this was one of the new inputs to the whole argument about what's been happening on Earth.
The critical things, I think, for the revolution in geological thought were, historically, first of all, Wegener, who before the first war, had very good arguments for
the idea that the continents had split and moved apart.
Wegener lost out, I think, for two reasons.
There was tremendous controversy in the 20s about this, very offensive papers about Wegener.
And he lost out for two reasons.
One, he wasn't a member of the right trades union.
He was a meteorologist, not a geologist.
Secondly, he mixed up good arguments with bad.
And if you have a difficult case to argue, you want to argue on your strong arguments.
Because otherwise people will refute the weak ones and think they refuted the whole thing.
